description: Here's how to transform a can of pinto beans into creamy, smoky refried beans.
headline: How To Transform a Can of Beans into the Best Refried Beans

HowtoTip.text: Store in an airtight container for up to three days.

name: How To Transform a Can of Beans into the Best Refried Beans
recipeIngredient: Chopped cilantro leaves and crumbled cotija cheese, for serving

recipeInstructions.text: Chop the ingredients. Chop 4 ounces thick-cut bacon into 1/2-inch pieces. Finely chop 2 garlic cloves, 1/2 medium yellow onion (about 1/2 cup), and 1/2 medium green bell pepper (about 1/2 cup).

Cook the bacon. Place the bacon in a medium regular or cast iron skillet over medium heat. Cook until the bacon is crisp, about 5 minutes. Using a slotted spoon, transfer the bacon to a small plate. Pour the bacon fat into a small heatproof bow, leaving a small amount in the pan to cook aromatics.

Cook the aromatics. Add the onion, bell pepper, garlic, and a pinch of kosher salt to the skillet and cook over medium heat until softened and translucent, about 5 minutes. Meanwhile, prepare the beans.

Reserve some bean liquid. Open 2 cans pinto beans. Pour off 1/3 cup bean liquid into a liquid measuring cup; keep the remaining beans and bean liquid in the cans. Add enough water to the measuring cup to reach 1 cup.

Add the bean liquid, beans, and bacon. Add the bean-water mixture and reserved bacon to the skillet. Stir to combine and bring to a simmer over medium heat. Add the beans and the remaining bean liquid from the cans. Bring to a simmer, stirring occasionally, and cook until the liquid has reduced by half or you can briefly see the bottom of the skillet when you stir, about 15 minutes.
Add the bacon fat and oil. Pour the reserved bacon fat into a measuring cup and add enough vegetable oil to reach 1/4 cup. Add the oil mixture to the beans and stir until combined.

Mash the beans. Reduce the heat to low. Mash the beans with a potato masher until most of the beans are broken down. The final texture should be a lumpy mash thatâ€™s still runny enough to pour. If the beans are too thick, stir in water a little at a time. Taste and season with kosher salt as needed. Top with chopped cilantro leaves and crumbled cotija for serving
